Award.AwardTitle: RIG: Role of Gbx transcription factors in development of sensory-motor circuits
Award.AbstractNarration: The precise assembly of neural circuits during development is critical in defining control of motor behaviors in the mature organism and remains a central problem in neurobiology. The focus of this project is to investigate the role of one family of DNA-binding proteins, gastrulation brain homeobox (Gbx), in the formation of neural circuits, which regulate motor functions, such as walking and eating. Gbx1 and Gbx2 are dynamically expressed in the developing nervous system and deficient expression of either has a deleterious effect on neural circuit development. This work will utilize molecular biology as well as genetic techniques and bioinformatics. Results from the project will provide valuable insights in to the function of Gbx proteins by identifying the genes which are under their direct control and are critical for positioning neuronal cells, guiding axons and ultimately, controlling motor behavior. Additional impacts of this award will be to help broaden the PI's scope in developmental neurobiology, molecular biology and bioinformatics, as well as contribute to his teaching and scholarly activities. Furthermore, training opportunities and the promotion of interdisciplinary research will be provided for students in an increasingly scientifically diverse and technology-driven society. The award will broaden participation of underrepresented minority graduate and undergraduate students by providing support for graduate student stipends and funding for research supplies. The experimental results of the research project will be published in scientific journals and students will be encouraged to present their findings at scientific meetings.

Intellectual Merit

Gastrulation brain homeobox (Gbx) transcription factors are DNA-binding transcription factors dynamically expressed in the developing central nervous system that regulate mechanisms required for patterning of neurons and axons in the anterior hindbrain and spinal cord. The focus of this research project was to investigate the role of Gbx transcription factors in assembly of neural circuits, specifically, (sensory-motor circuits) underlying motor behaviors in vertebrates, such as, suckling and walking. Our investigations approach this question at both the molecular/cellular and functional levels of the organism. In this project we use in vitro analyses, zebrafish, and our primary in vivo model system, the mouse, to test the hypothesis that Gbx transcription factors mediate formation of sensory-motor circuits by directly regulating the expression of key molecules involved in positioning sensory neurons and organizing axonal projections.

Transcriptional control by GBX family members is mediated by binding target genes at cognate binding sites. Therefore, identifying chromatin fragments bound by Gbx and the related target genes constitutes a first step for analysis of GBX transcription factors in regulating development of sensory-motor circuits. To date, an accurate description of GBX transcription factor function in neural circuit development has not been described through an understanding of their genomic binding sites or protein/protein interactions with transcriptional co-factors. The studies of this project, have led to several major insights related to the impact of GBX at the molecular and cellular levels of sensory motor-circuit assembly.

We have identified a panel of DNA-regulatory elements directly bound by GBX2. Our findings have led to several major insights related to the impact of GBX at the molecular and cellular levels of sensory motor-circuit assembly. First, we have determined more than 286 highly significant candidate target genes, falling into various functional groups. Strikingly, fifty-one percent are expressed in the nervous system. Moreover, many of the top candidate genes are plausible candidates contributing to the developmental defects in Gbx2 null mice. Importantly, several of the top candidate genes, have been shown to function in many aspects of sensory-motor circuits development. For example several GBX2 target genes have been shown to function in aspects of motor and sensory neuron patterning and control of axon growth and guidance. The original genome-wide data for all of the target genes has been made available through the Missouri Genome Browser (http://digbio.missouri.edu/gbx2/). Moreover, our analysis has revealed two novel GBX2 DNA-binding consensus motifs. Lastly, we have successfully progressed from the target gene identification stage of this project to target validation. Thus far, we have provided validation of several GBX2 target genes by both, in vitro and in vivo analyses.

Our studies show abnormal projection of proprioceptive sensory afferents (axons) into the dorsal spinal cord suggesting a disorganized assembly of proprioceptive sensory-motor circuitry within the spinal cord. Moreover, we show a marked loss of ventral motor neurons (MNs) during the late stages of gestation.
